messageBody:
We implemented a constraint oriented approach to solve this problem in
rMock. In my experience it works really well and is much easier than
try catch. RMock can not yet run in JUnit 4.0 but perhaps this can be
a source of inspiration:

public void testMethod() throws Exception {
expectThatExceptionThrown(is.instanceOf(SomeException.class));
out.doSomething();
}

It also allows some flexibility in the asserts, like this:

public void testMethod() throws Exception {
expectThatExceptionThrown(is.containing(by.exception.message("error
detail")).and(is.instanceOf(SomeOtherException.class));

out.doSomething();
}

I personally think it is much nicer than

try {
out.doSomething();
fail("expected...");
}
catch(...) {
// expected
}


I have not looked at jUnit 4.0 recently, the only thing I've seen is
@test(expected=<excecptionClass>)

couldn't that become

@test(expected=<constraint>)

instead?

I have not seen assertException but Anonymous classes seem more
tedious than a constraint toolbox. Where can I find more information
about JUnits assertException?

Regards
Joakim Ohlrogge
